discussion.content:
I think 'D' is correct answer.

L1 route injected by XR2 won't be advertised to XR1, since L2 routes are NOT leaked to L1 by default. An [L2-L1] route leak policy should be configured on L1/L2 router (XR3).
Of course D
The correct answer should be "D". The L2 to L1 leaking should happen on XR3.

La respuesta correcta es la C.
Porque por defecto las rutas de Level-2 nunca son propagadas a un Level-1
Yes, i think that correct is D too

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. A network operator is working to filter routes from being advertised that are covered under an aggregate announcement. The receiving router of the aggregate announcement block is still getting some of the more specific routes plus the aggregate. Which configuration change ensures that only the aggregate is announced now and in the future if other networks are to be added?

choices.A: Configure the summary-only keyword on the aggregate command
choices.B: Set each specific route in the AGGRO policy to drop instead of suppress-route
choices.D: Set each specific route in the AGGRO policy to remove instead of suppress-route
choices.C: Filter the routes on the receiving router

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is exact.
Source: https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/xr12000/software/xr12k_r4-0/routing/configuration/guide/rc40xr12k_chapter7.html#con_1117149

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. CE1 and CE2 cannot communicate through the service provider BGP peering is established between PE1 and PE2. IS-IS is the only routing protocol running in the service provider core. What step can be done to troubleshoot the issue?

discussion.content: 'D' is correct answer IMO
I think 'D' is correct answer. CE1 won't be able to talk to CE2 in case underlying MPLS LSP is failed

It doesn't say anything about the CE-PE routing. If that's in place and working fine, the answer is D. If not, routing between CE and PE should first be investigated and B makes more sense.
The question here is most probably incomplete.

Selected Answer: D
Must be D

Selected Answer: D
D is correct one!

Selected Answer: D
A: You are not going to chance the whole core IGP
B: Does not make sense to additionally run BGP here
C: How is a narrow metric going to help?
D: Makes sense to verify underlying protocol first.
i think its E tho
"C " is correct
I think its B

choices.C: Confirm that IS-IS is running with metric-style narrow.
choices.A: Switch the IGPs running in the core from IS-IS to OSPF to support a Cisco MPLS TE tunnel from PE1 to PE2.
choices.B: Configure BGP between CE and PE routers.

discussion.content: Because it should be the second best path from R1 point of view.

comments.content: Beacuse of the cost R1<==> R2 cost 10, R2 <==> R3 cost 8, total cost = 18

discussion.content: Does anybody know why R2 is the next hop instead of R4 which has a shorter distance to R3?

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which router does R1 install as an alternate next hop when trying to reach R3 if LFA is enabled?

discussion.content:
Key rollover is supported.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/routers/crs/software/crs_r6-1/routing/configuration/guide/b-routing-cg-crs-61x/b-routing-cg-crs-61x_chapter_010.html#con_1446789 section BP keychains
Yes, Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) supports only HMAC-MD5 and HMAC-SHA1-12.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. P1 and PE3 Cisco IOS XR routers are directly connected and have this configuration applied. The BGP session is not coming up. Assume that there is no IP reachability problem and both routers can open tcp port 179 to each other. Which two actions fix the issue? (Choose two.)

choices.E: Remove the send and accept lifetime under key 1
